title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Thing That Fixed My Winter Skin
body:
Okay so my skin is a mess. It’s always been a mess. I have this weird combination where my forehead gets shiny by noon but my cheeks and jawline feel like sandpaper, especially in winter. Like, actual sandpaper. It would get so tight and flaky that smiling felt like a chore. I’d put on foundation and it would just sit on top of all the little flakes, highlighting every single one. Great look.

I’ve tried everything. The expensive stuff in the frosted glass jars. The drugstore stuff with the cartoon characters. The Korean ten-step routine that took an hour every night. Some of it made me break out. Some of it just sat there, greasy. Most of it did absolutely nothing except make my bank account sadder. My bathroom cabinet looked like a skincare graveyard. I was about to just give up and accept my fate as a human lizard.

Then I saw someone talking about beef tallow balm. For your face. I was scrolling on my phone, it was late, my neighbor’s TV was blaring some infomercial through the wall. I remember because the sound was so annoying I almost threw a slipper. Beef fat. On your skin. My first thought was, “That’s disgusting.” My second thought was, “...But what if it’s not?”

I was desperate. And curious. So I ordered this Whipped Tallow Balm in Lavender from some small shop on Etsy. The description said it was made in France from grass-fed cows, whipped up into this creamy thing. It promised to be calming, good for sleep. My skin was keeping me up at night from how itchy it was, so why not.

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

It arrived in a little jar. I opened it up, fully expecting it to smell like a butcher shop. It didn’t. It smelled like… lavender. But not the fake, candle-store lavender. More like the dried lavender my grandma used to keep in her linen closet. A real, herby, kind of dusty smell. Not sweet. Just… plant-like. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold butter that’s been sitting out for twenty minutes. I scooped a tiny bit and rubbed it between my fingers. It melted. It got oily, but not in a gross way. More like… slick.

I was standing in my bathroom, in my sweatpants, at like 11 PM on a Tuesday. I thought, “Well, I paid for it.” So I put a little dab on my cheek. Then my other cheek. Then my forehead. I massaged it in. It felt heavy for a second, this layer of oil. I braced for the breakout of the century. I went to bed feeling like a glazed donut.

Here’s the weird part. When I woke up, my skin didn’t feel greasy. It felt… normal. My sandpaper cheeks were just… skin. They were soft. Not “product soft” but like, my own skin soft. I didn’t have that tight, screaming feeling when I moved my face. I was confused. I touched my face all morning like a weirdo.

So I kept using it. Just at night. After I washed my face, I’d take a little scoop—about the size of a pea—warm it up in my hands, and pat it all over. I’d smell the lavender and it did actually feel calming. It became this little ritual. The whole “beef tallow for skin” thing stopped being weird and started being just… my night cream.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

I’m not a scientist. I don’t know the molecular reason. But from what I read when I was falling down the internet rabbit hole, beef tallow is supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. So it sinks in instead of sitting on top. It doesn’t just mask the dryness; it seems to tell my skin to chill out and stop freaking out.

My main issue was this awful winter damage. My hands, from washing them a million times a day, would get red and cracked at the knuckles. They hurt. So one night, after I did my face, I rubbed the leftover balm on the back of my hands. Just the leftovers. The next day, the cracks looked less angry. After a few days, they were just… gone. Healed. I started using it on my elbows, which are permanently rough. They’re smooth now. I don’t know when that happened.

That’s the thing with this tallow balm. You don’t have a dramatic “before and after” photo moment. It’s not that. It’s more subtle. It’s like your skin just slowly decides to be okay. The flakiness on my jawline? Gone. The tight feeling after a shower? Gone. My skin just feels… balanced. It doesn’t feel like I’m wearing anything. It just feels like healthy skin, which is a sentence I never thought I’d say.

I even used it on a little patch of what I think was psoriasis on my leg. My doctor called it “winter eczema” or something. It was always there, itchy and scaly. I started putting the tallow on it after my shower. It took a couple weeks, but the patch got smaller. The itching stopped. Now it’s just a faint pink memory. I’m not saying it’s a miracle cure, but for me, it worked better than the prescription cream that cost ten times as much.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of Tallow

I’m on my second jar now. I ordered it from the same Etsy shop, the one that makes it in France. I didn’t even look for another brand. This one works, so why mess with it?

The best way I can describe it is that my skin has quit fighting me. It’s not a battle anymore. I don’t have to layer three different moisturizers and hope for the best. I just wash my face, put on this one thing, and go to bed. In the morning, my face isn’t screaming for moisture. It’s just… content. I can even skip a day if I’m lazy, and it’s fine. My skin doesn’t immediately revert to the Sahara Desert.

My makeup goes on better now. No more flake-highlighting. I use less of everything because my skin isn’t trying to drink it all up in one second. I told my mom about it. She has super dry, sensitive skin that gets red from everything. She was skeptical too. “Beef fat, really?” But she tried it. Now she texts me to remind me to order her a jar when she’s running low. That’s the biggest endorsement I can give.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did.

Look, if you’re like me and you’ve tried every “natural moisturizer for dry, sensitive skin” under the sun with zero luck, this might be worth a shot. It sounds bizarre. I know. Putting beef tallow on your face sounds like something from a hundred years ago. But sometimes the old things are old for a reason. They work.

It’s not magic. It won’t make you look 20 again. But if your skin is rough, cracked, flaky, or just generally pissed off at the world (and the weather), a good tallow balm might just calm it down. This lavender one is my favorite because the scent is part of the whole relaxing, end-of-day thing. It’s not a perfume. It’s just a quiet, herby smell that tells my brain it’s time to shut off.

I keep it on my nightstand. The little jar is almost empty again. Time to order a third.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Seems to be, for a lot of people. The idea is that it’s really close to the sebum our skin makes naturally, so it gets absorbed well instead of clogging stuff up. It worked for my weird combo skin, which is a miracle.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me, and I’m super prone to clogged pores on my forehead and chin. If anything, my skin is clearer. I think because it’s so moisturizing, my skin stopped over-producing oil to compensate. But everyone’s different. Start with a little.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like actual lavender plants. Not candy. Not soap. It’s earthy and herbal and a little dry, like crushed flowers. It’s not strong. It’s just there, and it’s really calming before bed.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult this winter, or any time really, maybe give a tallow balm a look. It’s the weirdest thing that’s ever worked for me. And now I’m a believer.
